decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The facing materials used in the development to which this permission relates shall match those of the existing building(s) unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on Surbiton Hill Park. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Consultations5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments:  The proposed development has not been fully assessed in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. The plans provided do not accurately represent the proposed development. Therefore officers cannot accurately consider whether there would be any adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: As mentioned above, the plans provided do not accurately represent the proposed development and therefore officers cannot accurately consider whether there would be an adverse impact on the amenities of the adjoining neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: As mentioned above, the plans provided do not accurately represent the proposed development and therefore officers cannot accurately consider the impact of the proposed development on fire safety. In conclusion, the proposed development would be contradictory with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a part two/part three storey building comprising a mixture of residential and light commercial use. This application relates specifically to the second floor flat known as 5A Chancery House.The site is located within a mixed residential/commercial use area and in the Tolworth Key Area of change and subject to an Article 4 Direction that removes permitted development rights for change of use from commercial, business and service use (Use Class E) to residential use (Use Class C3).ProposalPlanning permission is sought for the installation of 6 nos side rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Alteration to rear windows.The internal loft space is existing and would accommodate a bedroom and ensuite to Flat 5A. The flat would remain a one bedroom but would extend over two floors instead of one as existing.The proposal would not result in any loss of commercial space.Consultations64 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area;- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers, and;- Fire Safety.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed loft conversion comprises the installation of 6 x side roof lights (4 on one side and 2 on the other side elevation), and 2 x circular rooflights to the front and rear elevations. No objection is raised to the external design and appearance of the building.It is therefore considered that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character or appearance of the main dwelling and immediate surrounding area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Given the siting and nature of the proposed works and that there would be no increase in the intensity of use, it is not considered there would be any adverse impacts on the amenities of neighbouring occupants.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would be in accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultants and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to  Conditions 7 (Sustainable Homes) and 13 (Noise Insulation) of planning permission 18/12192/FUL, which states: Conditions 7 (Sustainable Homes) - Prior to the occupation of the approved development, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the CO2 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1_ standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day.Conditions 13 (Noise Insulation) -Prior to the occupation of the residential units hereby permitted, a scheme of noise insulation/reduction shall be submitted to and approved in writing. This scheme should ensure that a noise level of 35 dBLAeq,1 6 hour in living rooms and bedrooms during the daytime (0700 to 2300 hour) and 30 dBLAeq, 8 hour and 45 dBLAeqmax during the night time (measured with F time weighting and between 2300 and 0700 hours) in bedrooms in accordance with BS8233:2014 is not exceeded. Where these levels cannot be met with windows, open appropriate acoustic ventilation should be provided so that the room can be sufficiently ventilated. The acoustic performance of any passive vent, variable speed mechanical air supply unit or whole house ventilation must be sufficient to ensure that the noise level standards given above are not compromised

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site is a former commercial site on Kingston Hill situated to the rear of a run of properties west of Queens Road and accessed via a vehicle access between 53 and 55 Kingston Hill situated opposite the Kingston Hospital grounds.The area is mixed in use and the site is located in the designated heritage asset the Liverpool Road Conservation Area. The buildings and curtilage on or adjacent the site are not litsed.Proposal A section 73 application is sought to vary plans condition 2 of planning permission 16/13202/FUL to make a minor change to the approved floor levels. The overall building would still be 9.31m to the ridge with a small change proposed to the floor to ceiling heights a decrease of 25mm at ground and first floor level to maintain the approved building height. It should be noted that the description of development erroneously stated site level changes were sought. However the applicant has confirmed that changes to the site levels are not sought and this reference to site levels has been omitted from the original description of development.Consultation3 objections have been received. The objections are summarised as follows - Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Loss of light/Sunlight- Privacy- Inappropriate design/layoutOfficer comment: The objections are addressed in the officers assessment.One objection in particular raises points of concern to particular elements of the submission and are lifted from the objection below and an officer response provided. Objection - It is an incomplete submission - the updated plans do not include a rear elevation drawing, so theimpact of the retrospective change cannot be compared to the original drawing: 16_ 13202_FUL-PROPOSED_CROSS_SECTION_AND_REAR_ELEVATION-3  Officer response. On consultation with the applicant they have responded that the levels to the rear are the same as those to the front. . The site is entirely flat as it consists of made ground hence levels are consistent throughout. Site levels are indicated on plan P010-P01-R1. Officers are satisfied that the levels on the topography survey accompanying the original permission have not changed as shown in the application under consideration and the applicant has confirmed they are not seeking to change the site levels. References to site levels is erroneous in the description of development and has been amended to remove this.objection - Section 2.7 of PLANNING_STATEMENT-4564003, includes approved and proposed heights thatare not comparable, specifically Level 03 (to ridge) being compared to Level 03 (to ceiling).Officer response. On consultation with the applicant they have responded that the overall height of the building is identical to the planning permission. i.e. 9310 above finished ground level. The internal floor to ceiling levels are 3075mm on the built drawings whereas the floor-to floor levels on the approved MAA drawings are 3100mm. 3100mm is not buildable as it does not course to brickwork, hence we have reduced to 3075mm which does course. The 25mm difference is the sole purpose of the S73 application for minor material amendment which we have discussed at length. The internal floor-to-floor heights have no impact to anyone other than the occupant and are in fact lower than the approved drawings. Officers accept this reasoning and are satisfied that the only change is the floor to ceiling heights and assessment of this change is made in the officers assessment.Objection - The revised drawing: P-200_PROPOSED_CROSS_SECTION___FRONT _ELEVATION-4566070 is incorrect - the reality is that the development ground level is higher (and will be evenhigher once finished) to the ground level of the rear gardens of 3 & 5 & 7 Queens Road. Officer comment: On consultation with the applicant they have responded that All levels on site are unchanged from before as indicated on our drawing PA010-P01-R1 and are unchanged from existing. All stipulations of the planning approval have been complied with. Officers are satisfied that this is the case that the only change sought is to the floor to ceiling heights.Objection - Plans need to be submitted that accurately reflect the elevations with respect to the surrounding properties and section 2.7 to be updated. Officer comment: On consultation with the applicant they have responded that The drawings submitted are entirely accurate, entirely as-built, and entirely in accordance with the planning permission. Officers are satisfied that this is the case.Objection These concerns remain outstanding:1. Garden Elevation - Water DrainageThe elevated gardens will result in the risk of water flowing away to the surrounding properties of at least 3,5 & 7 and 9 Queens Road in the event of heavy rain. Officer comment: On consultation with the applicant they have responded that The entire site is sustainably drained using soakaways. There is no evidence of any flooding of surrounding properties which are generally higher than our development. The substrata is completely porous made ground and has passed percolation tests carried out on site to confirm this. Officers are satisfied with this response and are not revisiting these matters as the application relates solely to a change to a floor to ceiling height internally. Objection 2. Garden Elevation - PrivacyThe elevated garden will reduce privacy for surrounding properties. Officer comment: On consultation with the applicant they have responded that The buildings are constructed entirely in accordance with the approved planning drawings. This allows for privacy screens etc. There are no privacy issues other than what would normally be expected in an urban development of this type. Officers are satisfied with this response and have addressed matters of amenity in the assessment and the change in floor to ceiling height is not considered to impact on the privacy of neighboursObjection 3. Overall Building HeightThe overall building height in relation to the surrounding properties willi be higher than what has been approved in the plans. Officer comment: On consultation with the applicant they have responded that The building is identical to the approved building plans and at 9310mm above Ground Level is the same height as the planning permission. Officers are satisfied with this response and are satisfied that no change in site levels is proposed and that the building height above finished ground level would not be different to the approved scheme.Objection It's noted that:a The height of this development was approved to be below the height of the properties on the Queens Road side and those of the two 3 storey houses at The Farthings, thus reducing the dominant impact this build will have on the existing neighbours. Officer comment: On consultation with the applicant they have responded that The building is identical to the approved building plans and at 9310mm above Ground Level is the same height as the planning permission. There is no change whatsoever to the existing site levels. Officers are satisfied with this response and are satisfied that there is no change in the site levels. Objection b The concern is that if the ground level is higher than the plans, the overall building height will be above those of the surrounding properties which has been explicitly referenced in the approved plans and will result in a 'Dominant Impact' on the surrounding properties. Officer comment: On consultation with the applicant they have responded that The building is identical to the approved building plans and at 9310mm above Ground Level is the same height as the planning permission. The ground level is identical now to what it was before work commenced as indicated on drawing P010-P01-R1. Officers are satisfied with this response and are satisfied that there is no change in levels sought. Kingston CAAC: no objectionAssessmentThe proposed change in levels does not compromise the internal space standards of the approved building or the quantum or mix of units approved. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. The change in levels relates to a change to the internal floor to ceiling heights which shows a reduction of 25mm at ground and first floor to maintain the overall approved height 9.31m. It is considered that this minor change would not be readily obvious and is a subordinate change and would not change the overall character and appearance of the proposed development. The proposed change would not cause harm to the designated heritage asset the Liverpool Conservation Area. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. The height of the building does not increase with the minor change proposed. The change is a reduction in floor to ceiling height at ground and first floor to maintain the overall approved height of the building and as such it is considerd that this would not change the approved buildings relationship with the neighbouring properties and their occupiers. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.
